definition: head high, chest out (idiom); to keep up one's spirits/in fine mettle (of animal)
to lift/to raise/to raise one's head/high/high spirits/soaring/expensive
head/chief/first (occasion, thing etc)/classifier for poems, songs etc
straight/erect/to stick out (a part of the body)/to (physically) straighten up/to support/to withstand/outstanding/(coll.) quite/very/classifier for machine guns
chest/bosom/heart/mind/thorax
variant of 胸[xiong1]

sentences.english: The nation can hold its head up high.
As an aside, people who stand tall and confident are more attractive.
sentences.chinese: 另外，昂首挺胸站着的人更迷人。

sentences.english: The father and mother were at the head of the pack, standing proud as could be.
sentences.chinese: 他们的父母亲排在最前面，昂首挺胸地站着。

sentences.english: That is why I hold my head high and carelessly come into you presence.
sentences.chinese: 因此我昂首挺胸，随意走到你面前。

definition: striding forward with head high (idiom); to walk with spirited and vigorous step/to strut
high and mighty (idiom); arrogant
waist and back/fig. upright and still healthy
head high/in high spirits/to raise one's head (e.g. of neighing horse)
arrogant appearance/smug appearance/to act condescending/to put on airs
upright and unafraid
not to glance sideways (idiom)/to gaze fixedly/to be fully concentrated/to preserve a correct attitude
having high fighting spirit
to stride forward
majestic/awe-inspiring presence/impressive power
at a stride/taking large steps (while walking)
spirit trembling with excitement (idiom); in high spirits/lively and full of enthusiasm/full of energy/con brio
step with feet splayed outwards
full of vigor/spirited/valiant
to have an imposing or impressive appearance/impressive appearance/straight and impressive looking
a slow march
